column2: We can offer to vassalize all landed rulers of lower rank than us, though they will probably not accept unless they are much weaker than us and of our race and culture.
column3: We can offer to vassalize all landed rulers of lower rank than us, though they will probably not accept unless they are much weaker than us and of our race and culture.

column2: Characters from cultures that accept it can simply arrange a divorce settlement with their spouse.
column3: Characters from cultures that accept it can simply arrange a divorce settlement with their spouse.

column2: You will receive messages regarding independent rulers of the same Race as you
column3: You will receive messages regarding independent rulers of the same Race as you

column2: This map mode show the spread of all Race in Middle-Earth.
column3: This map mode show the spread of all Race in Middle-Earth.

column2: Race is a defining attribute of characters and determines which community they belong to. Characters of other Races are at best considered untrustworthy...
column3: Race is a defining attribute of characters and determines which community they belong to. Characters of other Races are at best considered untrustworthy...

column2: The Race of the populace is likely to affect the Race of characters born in the county.
column3: The Race of the populace is likely to affect the Race of characters born in the county.

column2: A guardian is a teacher and mentor to a child character. The skills, traits and culture of the guardian are likely to be passed on to the young ward.
column3: A guardian is a teacher and mentor to a child character. The skills, traits and culture of the guardian are likely to be passed on to the young ward.

column2: Adult characters can take on two children as their wards, passing on their skills, traits and culture.
column3: Adult characters can take on two children as their wards, passing on their skills, traits and culture.

column2: At age 6, children can be assigned a guardian for a proper upbringing. The choice is important, because the mentor will tend to pass on their skills, traits, culture and type of education to the child.
column3: At age 6, children can be assigned a guardian for a proper upbringing. The choice is important, because the mentor will tend to pass on their skills, traits, culture and type of education to the child.

column2: Opens a browser to the Tolkien Gateway page for this character
column3: Opens a browser to the Tolkien Gateway page for this character

column3: §YThis character has no Tolkien Gateway link§W

column2: You can offer to join rulers of your own Race in many types of wars.
column3: You can offer to join rulers of your own Race in many types of wars.

column2: §RNearby [Recipient.Religion.GetName] rulers might ask to join [Recipient.GetTitledName] in defense of their Race.§!
column3: §RNearby [Recipient.Religion.GetName] rulers might ask to join [Recipient.GetTitledName] in defense of their Race.§!

column2: The Decisions available to you depend on a number of factors, such as your character'sRace. There are many different Decisions that cover everything from inviting new nobles to holding grand tournaments.
column3: The Decisions available to you depend on a number of factors, such as your character'sRace. There are many different Decisions that cover everything from inviting new nobles to holding grand tournaments.

column3: Modifier to all Units and Holdings controlled by this Race:

column3: Additional Modifier in provinces of this Race:

column2: Setting this Unit to be a Looter will allow it to loot the provinces and holdings of other religions.\nThis will cause a temporary state of hostility with them however, allowing them to attack any of your troops
column3: Setting this Unit to be a Looter will allow it to loot the provinces and holdings of other religions.\nThis will cause a temporary state of hostility with them however, allowing them to attack any of your troops

column3: Will not join  enemies against members of your Race

column2: Peasants of a different religion group can rise up to throw off oppression and spread their faith with fire and sword.
column3: Peasants of a different religion group can rise up to throw off oppression and spread their faith with fire and sword.

column3: §RCannot Usurp the sole primary title off a ruler of another Race who still holds land within it

column2: The Authority determines the generic level privileges, rights and obligations for Vassals,
column3: The Authority determines the generic level privileges, rights and obligations for Vassals,

column2: Vassals are a law unto themselves, ruling their fiefs like petty kingdoms. Their obligations to their liege are minimal.
column3: Vassals are a law unto themselves, ruling their fiefs like petty kingdoms. Their obligations to their liege are minimal.

column2: Vassals enjoy a very large degree of autonomy, but have to provide their liege with a fairly substantial portion of the levies and tributes.
column3: Vassals enjoy a very large degree of autonomy, but have to provide their liege with a fairly substantial portion of the levies and tributes.

column2: The powers of vassals and the liege are in precarious balance.
column3: The powers of vassals and the liege are in precarious balance.

column2: The liege has curbed the rights of the vassals.
column3: The liege has curbed the rights of the vassals.

column2: The vassals are chafing under the unrestricted powers of the absolute liege.
column3: The vassals are chafing under the unrestricted powers of the absolute liege.

column2: Invent a reason for why a certain title should belong to you. It will cost Influence to make people accept this (though less if you have a de jure claim to it, or if your [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] is high.) The current title holder will not be pleased...
column3: Invent a reason for why a certain title should belong to you. It will cost Influence to make people accept this (though less if you have a de jure claim to it, or if your [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] is high.) The current title holder will not be pleased...

column2: Select a title to claim. Claiming a title costs Influence and will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you.
column3: Select a title to claim. Claiming a title costs Influence and will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you.

column2: Claim the §Y[ThirdPartyTitle.GetFullName]§W for §R$PRESTIGE$§W Influence. This will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you by §R$OPINION$§W.
column3: Claim the §Y[ThirdPartyTitle.GetFullName]§W for §R$PRESTIGE$§W Influence. This will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you by §R$OPINION$§W.

column2: Revoke a title from one of your vassals. It will infuriate the vassal, and, unless you have a claim on the title, will cost you Influence and anger your other vassals too.
column3: Revoke a title from one of your vassals. It will infuriate the vassal, and, unless you have a claim on the title, will cost you Influence and anger your other vassals too.

column2: Select a title to revoke. Revoking a title will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you. If you do not have a claim on the title or high enough Crown Authority, it will cost you Influence and anger your vassals.
column3: Select a title to revoke. Revoking a title will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you. If you do not have a claim on the title or high enough Crown Authority, it will cost you Influence and anger your vassals.

column2: Revoke the §Y[ThirdPartyTitle.GetFullName]§W for §R$PRESTIGE$§W Influence. This will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you by §R$OPINION$§W, and your other vassals' by §R$OPINION2$§W.
column3: Revoke the §Y[ThirdPartyTitle.GetFullName]§W for §R$PRESTIGE$§W Influence. This will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you by §R$OPINION$§W, and your other vassals' by §R$OPINION2$§W.

column2: Revoke the §Y[ThirdPartyTitle.GetFullName]§W. This will lower §Y[Recipient.GetTitledFirstName]§W's opinion of you by §R$OPINION$§W.

column2: You can hand out honorary titles to your courtiers, which will raise their opinion of you. Some honorary titles also come with minor estates (a source of income) and monthly Influence gain.
column3: You can hand out honorary titles to your courtiers, which will raise their opinion of you. Some honorary titles also come with minor estates (a source of income) and monthly Influence gain.

column2: Attacking an ally would cost us §R$PRESTIGE$§! Influence
column3: Attacking an ally would cost us §R$PRESTIGE$§! Influence

column2:
Marriage and the choice of a spouse is important for several reasons:
- You need to produce heirs lest your line end, and the game with it!
- Half of your spouse's attribute values are added to your own.
- You can call your in-laws to war (including those of your children and siblings)
- Characters gain influence by marrying above their rank
- Characters gain Influence by marrying into a influent Dynasty
column3:
Marriage and the choice of a spouse is important for several reasons:
- You need to produce heirs lest your line end, and the game with it!
- Half of your spouse's attribute values are added to your own.
- You can call your in-laws to war (including those of your children and siblings)
- Characters gain influence by marrying above their rank
- Characters gain Influence by marrying into a influent Dynasty

column2: Influence is a measure of your success and can be spent to carry out special actions. The Influence of each successive ruler you play is summed up and used to calculate your final score.
column3: Influence is a measure of your success and can be spent to carry out special actions. The Influence of each successive ruler you play is summed up and used to calculate your final score.

column2: You need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure Counties to create this title. Currently, you control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.
column3: You need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure Counties to create this title. Currently, you control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.

column2: You need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure Counties to usurp this title. Currently, you control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Usurping this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.
column3: You need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure Counties to usurp this title. Currently, you control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Usurping this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.

column2: Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§b Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§b Gold.
column3: Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§b Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§b Gold.

column2: Usurping this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.
column3: Usurping this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Influence and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.

column2: The Influence and [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] of each successive character you have played is added to your score at the time of their death. Your score will determine your final rank when the game ends.
column3: The Influence and [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] of each successive character you have played is added to your score at the time of their death. Your score will determine your final rank when the game ends.

column2: The influence of a dynasty is measured by the number and rank of titles ever held by its members, living and dead. A fraction of this sum is given to each new member of the dynasty at birth, and to anyone who marries a member of the dynasty.
column3: The influence of a dynasty is measured by the number and rank of titles ever held by its members, living and dead. A fraction of this sum is given to each new member of the dynasty at birth, and to anyone who marries a member of the dynasty.

column2: This is the Dynasty of this character. Some dynasties are more influent than others, depending on the number and rank of all landed titles ever held by their members, living and dead. A fraction of the Influence of both the mother and father's Dynasty is carried over to children born in wedlock. Spouses also get a fraction of each other's dynastic influence when marrying.
column3: This is the Dynasty of this character. Some dynasties are more influent than others, depending on the number and rank of all landed titles ever held by their members, living and dead. A fraction of the Influence of both the mother and father's Dynasty is carried over to children born in wedlock. Spouses also get a fraction of each other's dynastic influence when marrying.

column2: The Dynastic Heir is the legal successor to a character. If a player has no Dynastic Heir, the game will end. On succession, the Influence and [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] of a character is carried over to the Heir in the form of Score.
column3: The Dynastic Heir is the legal successor to a character. If a player has no Dynastic Heir, the game will end. On succession, the Influence and [Player.Religion.GetPietyName] of a character is carried over to the Heir in the form of Score.

column2: This vassal is not giving any Influence to you.\nSome buildings give Influence to the holder and the holder's liege.
column3: This vassal is not giving any Influence to you.\nSome buildings give Influence to the holder and the holder's liege.

column2: The titles of the ruler are divided among his children, with the oldest getting the primary title. If the ruler has no children who can inherit, the law defaults to Primogeniture. You get no Influence penalty for having unlanded sons, and can have a §Y30%§! larger demesne. Gavelkind is a very popular law with everyone except the oldest child. Destruction of titles while under Gavelkind succession is not allowed.

column2: You can revoke honorary titles that you have awarded to characters, depriving them of the Influence and income from those titles.
